text:
Q: In Ada using an enumeration type variable/instance as loop index in loop with case of each enumeration value A:

There are no rendering problems of Ada code! Probably, only code coloring is not implemented, but it is not important at all.

I've tried to edit your first code sample (not sure this is what you mean, please check up after the approval) — all works.

You have to use correct Markdown and, first of all, break your code text into lines correctly.

Q: What is the difference between "#!/usr/bin/env bash" and "#!/usr/bin/bash"? A:

The main point of #!/usr/bin/env bash is that #!bash will not search $PATH and will print:

test.sh: bash: bad interpreter: No such file or directory

Thus, if you don't want to provide an absolute path to the script interpreter - because it is unclear where it's located (Is it in /bin or in /usr/bin or in /opt/bin or in /home/user/bin?) - then using a program that searches $PATH, which happens to be /usr/bin/env in Linux, is your only option of how to start a script.

Q: How do I resolve `state_mismatch` error with Google OAuth in a Next.js app using Better Auth? A:

The is most likely stems from trying to manage cookies with plugins: [nextCookies()], so remove this and try I had the same issue i resolved with removing the logic I was trying to manage cookies on my own.

Q: How to set the default value of radio buttons after loading page? A:

For radio buttons or checkboxes you can use .val() using an array of values.

$radios.val( [ ] ); // uncheck all radios
$radios.val( [ "fin" ] ); // check the radio with value "fin"
$radios.val( [ "courant" ] ); // check the radio with value "courant"
$radios.val( [ "fin", "courant" ] ); // not useful in radio button context, but you can use this for checkboxes

Q: how can I avoid storing a command in ipython history? A:

I'm surprised that this solution didn't pop-up earlier, but anyway.

I think the answer is simple, don't put anything in the history that should not be there. How to achieve that? Use getpass

from getpass import getpass

secret = getpass() # you will get a password prompt

# your sensitive code is not sensitive anymore
app = myapi.login(user='peter',pass=secret)
app.do_your_stuff()

There is nothing to delete from the history because there is nothing sensitive. Unless you are using ipython to watch p0rn, I believe that getpass is the answer to your problem.
